title: Coronavirus updates, May 14: Quebec pumps up economy, delays reopening Montreal schools
text:
Share this Story: Coronavirus updates, May 14: Quebec pumps up economy, delays reopening Montreal schools

Coronavirus updates, May 14: Quebec pumps up economy, delays reopening Montreal schools It's unclear whether businesses can start up on May 25, but the reopening of daycares is delayed until at least June 1 Photo by John Mahoney / Montreal Gazette

Article content This post was updated throughout the day on Thursday, May 14. We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

Anxiety higher among Quebec immigrants, visible minorities More below 4:50 p.m. Montreal elementary schools will not reopen until August or September Following up on the press conference I covered earlier, here’s our full story, by René Bruemmer, about Quebec’s decision to delay reopening Montreal schools and daycares and the tentative plan to reopen businesses on May 25. 3:50 p.m. Quebec will advance $2.9B in infrastructure spending Quebec this afternoon announced that it will advance $2.9 billion in infrastructure spending. The move will “inject more money, more quickly into the Quebec economy,” Premier François Legault said via Facebook.

Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content He said the extra spending will “reduce the economic impact of the (COVID-19) crisis and ensure a strong recovery.” Quebec now plans to spend $13.9 billion on infrastructure, up from the planned $11 billion. Much of extra money will go toward health, education, road and public-transit projects, the government said. 3:25 p.m. Mortgage crunch Many Canadians who are out of work due to the pandemic are struggling to pay their mortgages. Banks say 722,000 have asked to skip or put off payments. Today, the Bank of Canada released estimates of mortgage-holders’ liquid assets. Bank of Canada: "About 20 percent of all mortgage borrowers do not have enough liquid assets to cover two months of mortgage payments" pic.twitter.com/WiqOrITdpD — Scott Barlow (@SBarlow_ROB) May 14, 2020

She also thanked Premier François Legault for his promise to help Montreal distribute masks. Here’s what Plante had to say: We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

Article content 3:05 p.m. Legault defends Quebec remote-learning resources Some Quebec parents have not been impressed by the remote-learning resources the province’s Education Department has provided to students so far. Premier François Legault was asked about this today. Here’s his response. We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

Article content 3 p.m. You can donate all those empties to a good cause With many stores not accepting them due to pandemic restrictions, empty returnable cans and beer bottles are piling up in Quebecers’ garages. On the next three Saturdays, some Montreal-area IGA, Metro and Super C grocery stores will set up drop-off points for the returnables in their parking lots, with money raised going to charity. The first donation day – Saturday, May 16 – will take place in seven boroughs: Ahuntsic-Cartierville, Lachine, LaSalle, Rivière-des-Prairies–Pointe-aux-Trembles, St-Laurent, Ville-Marie and Villeray–Saint-Michel–Parc-Extension. They will be open from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. The collections are a joint effort by the grocery store chains and Jour de la Terre, organizer of Quebec Earth Day events.

Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content For more information, including addresses of the drop-off points, visit this page on the Jour de la Terre page. 2:45 p.m. Quebec restaurant owners want to reopen, even at half-capacity: poll Most Quebec restaurant operators are keen to reopen even with fewer tables, though many fear that the COVID-19 crisis could make it increasingly difficult to find staff. Read our full story, by Frédéric Tomesco. 2:40 p.m. Opinion: Anglos’ COVID-19 anxiety should be understood, not deflected “It was regrettable to hear Premier François Legault diminish the sincerely expressed anxieties of many English-speaking Quebecers, most of whom are concentrated on the island of Montreal, where he has regularly reminded us that the number of cases and fatalities are the highest in the province.”

Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content Read the full op-ed, by Jack Jedwab, president of the Association for Canadian Studies. 2:15 p.m. Updated charts, maps 2:10 p.m. Quebec delays reopening Montreal schools, records 131 new deaths Schools in Greater Montreal will not reopen until late August/early September, Premier François Legault announced this afternoon, describing the situation in the region as “fragile.” Children had been scheduled to return to class on May 25. He made the announcement at a joint press conference with Mayor Valérie Plante. “I think it was the right thing to do,” Plante said of the delay. Quebec high schools are currently holding classes online, as are CEGEPs and universities. CEGEPs and universities have said most classes will be held online in the fall.

Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content Legault said he hopes high schools, CEGEPs and universities will hold at least some classes in person in the new school year. The reopening of daycares, also slated for May 25, is being delayed until at least June 1, the premier announced. Legault said the provincial government has not yet decided whether non-essential businesses in Greater Montreal will be allowed to reopen as scheduled on May 25. It will take “a few days” to decide whether businesses can reopen, he said. “I am convinced that we can regain control of the situation in Montreal.” Legault added that “it’s important that Montrealers wear masks (when leaving home), especially if we want to open businesses on May 25.” He said Quebec may make facial coverings obligatory on public transit.

Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content Legault said Ottawa has agreed to extend the military’s support in Quebec long-term-care centres (CHSLDs). Earlier today, federal Public Security Minister Bill Blair said soldiers will continue helping out in CHSLDs until June 12. Legault also provided updated figures: Quebec has 40,724 cases of COVID-19, an increase of 793 from yesterday.

The provincial death toll is now 3,351, an increase of 131.

Montreal Island alone has 20,633 cases and 2,154 deaths.

Quebec screened 13,291 people over the past 24 hours, still short of its 14,000-test target. Conférence de presse sur la COVID-19 | 14 mai 2020 On sait que la situation est bonne en dehors de la région de Montréal, mais elle reste fragile dans la communauté métropolitaine. C’est là que la pandémie a frappé le plus durement et que le confinement dure depuis le plus longtemps. Je remercie tous les Québécois de la région de Montréal de votre discipline et de votre patience. 🎥Suivez notre point de presse en direct 👇 Posted by François Legault on Thursday, May 14, 2020

Article content Legault and Plante had a private meeting this morning. Merci @francoislegault d’être avec nous à Montréal aujourd’hui. Continuons à travailler ensemble pour la sécurité et le bien-être de la population de la métropole. #polmtl #polqc https://t.co/f56iEJBRY3 — Valérie Plante (@Val_Plante) May 14, 2020

Article content 12:25 p.m. Students want Quebec universities to reduce tuition Following up on the Concordia University petition I wrote about earlier, here’s our full story about growing frustration among Quebec university students who want tuition fees cut because most classes will not be held in-person for the foreseeable future. 11:50 a.m. Anxiety higher among Quebec immigrants, visible minorities On Wednesday, results of an Association for Canadian Studies poll indicated that English-speaking Quebecers are more likely than francophones to be afraid of contracting COVID-19 and more likely to know an infected person. When Premier François Legault was asked about the findings, he blamed the anglophone media, singling out the Montreal Gazette.

Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content Today, ACS president Jack Jedwab has published more details, this time focusing on Quebec immigrants and visible minorities. He found that they are also more afraid of the disease than the provincial average. Jedwab said immigrants are: More anxious than non-immigrants, especially immigrants who have been in Canada for less than 10 years.

Far more likely to feel the economic impact of the virus and to want to slow the pace of de-confinement.

More likely than non-immigrants to be worried about a family member getting the virus.

More likely to know someone diagnosed with the virus. The findings also show that: Visible minorities are far more likely than others to fear getting the virus.

Quebec Jews are far more likely to be afraid of getting the virus than Christians and atheists.

Quebecers who are most anxious about the novel coronavirus have adhered most closely to the government’s advice on preventive measures.

Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content 11:30 a.m. Canada partially reopening national parks in June, Trudeau says Prime Minister Justin Trudeau this morning announced $470 million in emergency financial aid for fish harvesters. Those who expect a 25-per-cent drop in income this season will get up to $10,000 to cover losses, he said. Ottawa will also provide non-repayable grants of up to $10,000 for fish harvesters who own a business. And employment insurance benefits will be beefed up so harvesters can apply based on last year’s revenues, Trudeau said. He also announced “some good news for the weeks ahead” on national parks. As of the beginning of June, some national parks will be partially reopening, allowing Canadians to use some trails and green spaces where physical distancing is possible. Article content 11:05 a.m. Arruda apologizes, this time for comment about Montreal North Montreal North mayor Christine Black took to Facebook Tuesday to blast Quebec public health director Horacio Arruda for comments he made about what he said was a poor turnout for COVID-19 testing in the borough. Arruda backtracked and apologized a day later, saying, “I’m sorry if my information was wrong.” Read our full story, by Kathryn Greenaway. On Tuesday, Arruda apologized to anybody who may have been offended by a video in which he dances to a song by Quebec rapper Rod le Stod. 11 a.m. Ontario records lowest case growth rate since early March As Quebec continues to struggle with outbreaks, the situation is improving in Ontario. From The Canadian Press:

Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content TORONTO — Ontario is reporting 258 new cases of COVID-19 today and 33 more deaths. That brings Ontario to a total of 21,494 cases, a 1.2-per-cent increase over the previous day — the lowest growth rate since early March. The number of new cases is the lowest since late March. The total includes 1,798 deaths and 16,204 cases that have been resolved, which is now more than 75 per cent of the total. Hospitalizations increased, though the numbers of people in intensive care and on ventilators decreased. 10:45 a.m. Students urged to prepare before applying for emergency benefits Students can start applying for the Canada Emergency Student Benefit tomorrow. They can speed up the process by setting up their account with the Canada Revenue Agency, federal Employment Minister Carla Qualtrough says.

Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content You can find more information here, including details on who can apply and how the application process will work. From May to August, the CESB will provide payments of $1,250 per four-week period. The amount rises to $2,000 for those with dependants or a disability. Attention students! 📢



Starting May 15th, you can apply for the Canada Emergency Student Benefit. If you have not done so already, open a CRA MyAccount and sign up for direct deposits in order to get the CESB as quickly as possible.



For more info ➡️ https://t.co/et28FR7psv pic.twitter.com/hD604Qwuts — Carla Qualtrough (@CQualtro) May 13, 2020

Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content 10:30 a.m. Analysis: How Montreal’s CHSLDs mirrored the Diamond Princess outbreak As was the case with pre-symptomatic ship workers who unwittingly transmitted the coronavirus to confined passengers aboard the Diamond Princess, so have poorly equipped nurses and préposées aux bénéficiaires (orderlies) passed COVID-19 to the elderly residents of CHSLDs. Read the full story, by Aaron Derfel. 10:20 a.m. As they go mostly online, should Quebec universities cut tuition? With Quebec universities saying classes will be mainly online for the foreseeable future, some students are fighting back, arguing tuition fees should be reduced because they won’t have access to libraries and other facilities and services.

Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content At Concordia University, students have started a petition calling for a tuition reduction for the summer. As of 10:25 a.m., just under 4,000 students had signed. 10:15 a.m. Bank of Canada warns of excess debt from COVID-19 From The Canadian Press: OTTAWA — The Bank of Canada says there are signs in the country’s financial markets that suggest concern about the ability of companies to weather the COVID-19 economic crisis. The central bank has spent the last two months making a flurry of policy decisions that has seen it slash its target interest rate and embark on an unprecedented bond-buying program to ease the flow of credit. The report suggests these measures have helped ease liquidity strains and provide easy access to short-term credit for companies and households.

Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content But it is warning this morning that a cash-flow problem for businesses seeing sharp revenue declines during the crisis could soon develop into a solvency issue. The Bank of Canada says market prices point to a concern that defaults are likely to rise. The report also raises concerns that household debt levels are likely to rise and become acute for households whose incomes don’t fully recover from the pandemic. 9:45 a.m. Legault in Montreal to see situation firsthand Premier François Legault will be in Montreal for much of the day to see first-hand how officials are handling the pandemic in a region that has become Canada’s epicentre. He is expected to talk about the slow ramp-up of testing in Quebec. The province had hoped to be testing 14,000 people daily by now but so far has only reached 9,000.

Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content It’s the first time Legault has left Quebec City since the crisis began in mid-March. His schedule includes an 11 a.m. private meeting at his downtown Montreal office with Mayor Valérie Plante. At 1 p.m., Legault will hold a press conference at Place des Arts with Plante, and public-health directors Horacio Arruda and Mylène Drouin. At 4:30 p.m., the premier is to take part in a private meeting with regional health officials from across Greater Montreal. And Legault ends the day with a 6 p.m. conference call with Premier Justin Trudeau and other provincial premiers. 9:30 a.m. Gradual reopening of national parks, historic sites to be announced Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Environment Minister Jonathan Wilkinson are expected to announce today plans to begin a phased-in opening of federal parks and historic sites across the country.
